webTitle: US employment figures fuel fears job market recovery may have stalled

fields.bodyText: The department that deals with US unemployment fuelled fears that the country's job market recovery could have stalled when it said the economy added only 113,000 new jobs in January. Economists had been expecting around 180,000 new jobs, and this was the second month of disappointing jobs news from the department of labour, which last month surprised economists by saying that the US had added just 74,000 jobs in December, well below the 200,000 some had expected. That has been revised up to 75,000. Last year the economy added an average of 194,000 jobs per month. Official figures show the number of unemployed was little changed in January, at 10.2m, with the unemployment rate down just 0.1% to 6.6%. The percentage of the population in or looking for work edged up to 63% from a three-decade low of 62.8% last month. The number of long-term unemployed (those jobless for 27 weeks or more) fell by 232,000, but the figure was probably affected by the fact that a million Americans lost their extended federal unemployment benefits at the end of December. Even so, the figure remains high at 3.6m – making up 35.8% of the ranks of the unemployed. But stockmarkets on both sides of the Atlantic shrugged off the news to send share values up as analysts partly blamed the weather and traders focused on expectations of further economic strength. The FTSE 100 climbed 13 points to 6,571 while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 105 points to 15,733. Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody's Analytics, said: "Cold and stormy winter weather continued to weigh on the job numbers. Underlying job growth, abstracting from the weather, remains sturdy. Gains are broad-based across industries and company sizes, the biggest exception being manufacturing, which shed jobs – but that is not expected to continue." The jobs news comes against a background of steady improvement in many other areas of the US economy, pushing the annual rate of growth in the last three months of 2013 to 3.2%. Britain's outlook also improved after figures showed the trade deficit narrowed sharply in December, helped by rising exports to countries beyond Europe. The boost to the UK's trade position exceeded economists' expectations and raised hopes that exports finally helped lift the overall economy at the end of last year after dragging on growth over the summer. But a rise in manufacturing output of 0.3% in December showed the sector failed to grow as fast as hoped. The UK still has some way to go to squeeze its deficit to the level of France's, which was €61bn in 2013, and both countries lie well behind Germany, which registered a €200bn surplus last year. Analysts said the UK's figures failed to support the government's push to rebalance the economy away from consumer spending towards more manufacturing and exports. The deficit on trade in goods and services fell to an estimated £1bn in December, compared with a gap of £3.6bn in November, giving an annual trade deficit of £108.3bn. A fall in the number of insolvencies to an eight-year low in 2013 also cheered investors, though experts warned that already high levels of indebtedness could rise "in the not too distant future". The Insolvency Service said 101,000 people had become insolvent during the year, a fall of 7.9% on 2012's figure.

webTitle: Barclays: where smaller pies mean bigger slices for staff

fields.bodyText: • Tell us it's not true, saintly Antony. Have you really increased bonuses at Barclays' investment bank while revenues and profits are falling and shareholders are still digesting autumn's thumping £6bn rights issue? Are you already taking a detour from the "multi-year path to reposition Barclays remuneration", as last year's annual report piously put it? Barclays shareholders will learn on Tuesday with the full-year results that the reports are accurate. Chief executive Antony Jenkins and the board have indeed sanctioned an increase in bonuses at the investment bank in a year in which the unit's revenues fell. In other words, the pie has shrunk in size but the well-paid employees will receive a larger slice at the expense of investors. That is not what Barclays promised. "I hope that 2012 will be seen as a turning point in the way Barclays approaches remuneration," Sir John Sunderland, chairman of the pay committee, wrote in last year's annual report. "For 2012 and in future we are taking a different approach to the balance between directors' and employees' remuneration, and returns for shareholders." Jenkins may offer various explanations. The blasted EU bonus cap has sown confusion and Wall Street rivals are exploiting the situation by waving large carrots at Barclays' most prized staff. Thus the bank has had to respond in kind to remain competitive. This argument, as far as it goes, is coherent. It is true that the shareholders of JP Morgan et al are a feeble bunch and have been happy to let the bonus party roll on even as the bills for the last knees-up continue to pile up. Jamie Dimon's $20m (£15m) pay packet after another year of litigation hell at JP Morgan is merely the most striking example. But Jenkins should talk straight to his shareholders. He is clearly sincere about his clean-up programme; and he himself is prepared to share the pain for "legacy litigation and conduct issues" by declining a bonus for 2013. But is he also saying that Barclays, on pay, is still a prisoner of the demands of the senior staff in its investment bank? If so, where is the long-term gain for shareholders? The unit occasionally, as in 2012, earns returns in excess of Barclays' cost of capital, the true measure of profitability. But if, in the "down" years, new-look Barclays still feels the need to play the greed game to retain a seat at the table, what is the point of staying in investment banking? • Cold logic says AO, an online retailer of fridges, freezers and microwaves coming to the stock market next month, would be absurdly over-priced at £1bn. The company made top-line profits of only £10.7m last year on sales of £275m and margins on electrical goods are notoriously thin for the retailer. Gut instinct, however, says this flotation will generate a stampede of investors. AO is clearly a high-quality outfit. John Roberts, founder and 40% owner, has got something right if he has travelled this far on only £3m of investment and no bank borrowings. This does not seem to be a business that requires vast sums of capital to expand. The magic ingredients are claimed as smart logistics, proprietary IT and excellent customer service. All e-commerce companies make similar boasts, of course, but AO can at least point to proper profits, a rapid shift in its market towards online shopping and a route to expansion – Germany, in the first instance, plus the addition of TVs to the range. To justify a £1bn price-tag, you have to believe that AO's profit margins can rise substantially from last year's 3.8% with the benefits of greater size and that German expedition can be executed without cock-ups. Both propositions are untested and Dixons remains a strong competitor in the UK. So, in a rational world, £300m-ish for AO would more fairly reflect the risks and potential rewards of investment. But, if the stock market is willing to value loss-making Ocado at £3bn, there will be buyers for AO at £1bn. • Stephen Billingham, chairman of pub landlord Punch Taverns, declared last month that it would be "economically rational" for all parties to agree the terms of his take-it-or-leave-it deal for bondholders to restructure £2.3bn-worth of securitised debt. It was quite a claim as there are 16 classes of bonds and agreement is needed from each. Unfortunately for Billingham, holders of too many of those bonds don't share his assessment of economic self-interest. One irate bondholder describes the terms as "unacceptable" and the documentation as "unsignable". The chance of an 11th-hour agreement is roughly zero and the proposals will almost certainly be voted down next Friday. Several wet towels are required to understand the technicalities of all the quarrels here. The heart of the problem is that Punch was designed at the outset by financial engineers who did a botch-job. The junior bonds still get some access to income in the event of a default, which confuses the traditional hierarchy of creditors. Then matters became doubly complicated when some US hedge funds emerged as both shareholders and junior bondholders. It's messy. But one principle should surely be supreme in any debt restructuring: shareholders, as suppliers of the first line of risk-capital, are wiped out first, or at least diluted hugely. Senior bondholders, gathered under the Association of British Insurers' umbrella, have been arguing that point all along. They have been right to do so. The belligerent hedge funds who bought up Punch shares may have been gambling that, when push came to shove, fuddy-duddy ABI-types would roll over. The display of backbone by the ABI group should be applauded. The danger after Friday's vote is that Punch defaults on its obligations, creating yet more mess and confusion for everybody. But, if that happens, it's the shareholders who should be blamed.

webTitle: Need a Batcave? Company of fixers for super-rich ready to oblige

fields.standfirst: No (legal) request too rich for Quintessentially concierge company for millionaires, now expanding to developing countries
fields.body:
It might be hard, but try to imagine you're a billionaire who suddenly "needs" a pet jellyfish, or you're the scion of an uber-wealthy family and have a sudden urge to convert one of your many spare rooms into a Batcave. There's only one person to call (possibly on your batphone).

Emma Sherrard Matthew, chief executive of Quintessentially, a concierge company for millionaires, promises that she can get you anything your heart desires – from help with your children's homework to buying your partner the perfect birthday present, or even organising your marriage proposal – if you are rich enough.

Most of the requests are for tables at the hippest fully-booked restaurants or tickets to sold-out events.

But occasionally Matthew is pushed to deliver on the company motto that "nothing is too big or too small (as long as it is legal)".

Recent demands from members, who shell out £24,000-a-year for the privilege, have stretched from persuading a world-class tenor to perform at an intimate surprise party to sending a circus troupe to a child's birthday in Dublin – both tasks a doddle compared with the jellyfish and batcave.

Matthew's team of 1,000 fixers – managed from Quintessentially's grand townhouse headquarters among the embassies of Portland Place – were given half a day to find the pet jellyfish when a member suddenly decided that medusozoa were this season's absolute must-have accessory.

The fixers, who are hired on the basis of their connections, convinced the manager of an aquarium to personally install the tank and jellyfish and give the proud new owner a 30-minute lecture on the difficulties of keeping a jellyfish healthy at home.

An "elite" Quintessentially "lifestyle manager" was seconded to oversee the Batcave project from start to finish. Top-name landscape architects and interior designers were hired to create an "authentic-looking Batcave" reached, naturally, through a secret door from the library.

Despite the hefty membership fee, which must be paid up front each year and is equivalent to the cost of employing a personal assistant, Matthew says the promise to be a billionaire's "little best friend in your top pocket" has proved immensely popular.

There's a waiting list to join as a member in London because the company – established by Ben Elliot, a nephew of the Duchess of Cornwall, and two friends in 2000 – has capped membership in the UK at 5,000.

Matthew says people are queueing up to have access to her "super-well connected" team, which can get you into "the best nightclubs, the best restaurants and get you access to sporting events around the world".

When a spot in the club opens up, membership does not necessarily go to the next in line.

Potential members have to be mega-rich to join, but Matthew believes it's vulgar to enquire about someone's wealth. "We don't ask them what's in their bank account. We don't do credit checks," she says. "But by asking intelligent questions we get an idea of their net worth."

Once membership is granted, clients are interviewed so that the company knows what members might like before they even ask for it. "We profile them when they join to find out how they travel, how many homes they have around the world and how they wish to use us as a service."

She says the key selling point of the service is the links her team build with the maitre d's at top restaurants, theatre managers, ticket agents (both official and black market) and even the admissions officers at top private schools. "We've got incredible relationships with the key people that are there. They help get us access." It is for those links and that access, Matthew says, that her members – who include Jemima Khan, Sophie Dahl and Tatjana von Bismarck – are really paying. For help with their everyday lives, she explains, most of her clients have a PA (if not several).

"Let's say you're a billionaire with an army of people around you. A lot of assistants don't necessarily fly with them. Their assistants are still in Hong Kong. Maybe they've never been to London before but they want to get into the Wolseley or another great restaurant or night club," she says. "How much easier to call your elite account manager here, who can meet you off the plane and chauffeur you around and be your support on the ground."

The company has expanded to New York, Hong Kong, Russia, Dubai and a dozen other locations, and is now following the money trail to developing countries. Offices have recently opened in Nigeria, Indonesia, Morocco, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

The latest project is Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, where a mining boom is under way. The city has been dubbed the "Kuwait of Central Asia".

Luxury brands such as Louis Vuitton, Emporio Armani and Burberry have opened stores there and Porsches and Hummers cruise the streets. "They need us," Matthew explains. "Mongolians are travelling now and they want to know where to go and what to see."

Oligarchs and their pampered offspring are also a growing market for Quintessentially's army of young fixers, who sit eating their Boots £3.29 meal deal sandwiches at their desks while booking tropical holidays for their super-rich clients.

Matthew has hired 20 Russian speakers to a dedicated and expanding Russia desk, in the grade-II listed London headquarters designed and built by Robert Adam. The team helps new Russian members "find the very best properties, advice and support on leading London schools and tutors for their children, and sourcing Russian speaking staff, especially nannies, for their home".

Other popular requests from the oligarch set include "daily private jet travel" between Moscow and London.

What next? Matthew is, as always, following the money – and that means new, dedicated Chinese and Arabic-speaking desks in London.

webTitle: Anglo Irish Bank trial: day three

fields.standfirst: Jury hears minutes of a meeting between Sean Quinn and the Irish regulator in 2008, while most of the day was taken up with cross examination of former Quinn Group CEO Liam McCaffrey
fields.body:
As his debts soared to billions of euros, Ireland's one-time richest man Sean Quinn admitted to the Republic's financial regulator that he needed to be "reined in" over his borrowings from the now defunct Anglo Irish Bank, the trial of three bankers heard on Friday.

Minutes of a meeting between Quinn and the regulator Pat Neary in 2008 – the year Anglo Irish and his own business empire started to crumble – revealed that the ex-billionaire also accepted he had "been greedy" in buying a share scheme in the bank, the court was told.

Referring to himself in the third person during the discussion with the Irish state's financial overseer, he said "Sean Quinn needs to be reined in", the jury was told inside Dublin's central criminal court.

During the trial of three Anglo Irish Bank executives – Sean FitzPatrick, Patrick Whelan and William McAteer – details emerged of how Sean Quinn became swamped with debts from loans he took to buy shares in the bank.

The trio are charged with making unlawful financial payments to 16 people in 2008, including Sean Quinn, who by the summer of that year owed €2.5bn (£2.1bn) in loans. All three men pleaded not guilty on Wednesday at the opening of what will be the longest trial in Irish criminal history and one of the biggest of its kind in Europe. The case is expected to last until the end of May and will involve hundreds of witnesses, and the examination of millions of documents.

Quinn borrowed billions not only to buy shares in the bank but to also fund a global property portfolio. The financial crisis in 2008, the world property crash and Anglo Irish Bank's collapse led to him being bankrupted. Anglo Irish Bank was rescued with billions of euros from Irish and European taxpayers and then nationalised. Quinn's losses personified the demise of the Celtic Tiger years of extraordinary growth much of it fuelled with easily available credit.

Although the bankrupted former billionaire turned up in court on Friday, most of the day was taken up with cross examination by one of the Anglo trio's lawyers of Quinn's former CEO Liam McCaffrey. Patrick Whelan's lawyer asked McCaffrey if Sean Quinn had lost billions on a "spectacular punt" on shares through contracts for difference, which are bets on future shares in a company.

The former head of the Quinn Group of companies replied: "He paid a very high price for investing in that bank."

The lawyer for Whelan, Brendan Grehan, said in 2008 the Quinn family had "handed over the keys of the shop" to the bank after it put its businesses up as security for further loans from Anglo Irish. Earlier the court heard that Quinn was "eternally optimistic" about the shares in Anglo Irish Bank recovering in price despite them plummeting in the year of the financial crash. Sean Quinn meanwhile is now expected to give evidence at the trial on Monday morning. The case continues.

Referring to himself in the third person during the discussion with the Irish state's financial overseer, he said "Sean Quinn needs to be reined in", the jury was told inside Dublin's central criminal court. During the trial of three Anglo Irish Bank executives – Sean FitzPatrick, Patrick Whelan and William McAteer – details emerged of how Sean Quinn became swamped with debts from loans he took to buy shares in the bank. The trio are charged with making unlawful financial payments to 16 people in 2008, including Sean Quinn, who by the summer of that year owed €2.5bn (£2.1bn) in loans. All three men pleaded not guilty on Wednesday at the opening of what will be the longest trial in Irish criminal history and one of the biggest of its kind in Europe. The case is expected to last until the end of May and will involve hundreds of witnesses, and the examination of millions of documents. Quinn borrowed billions not only to buy shares in the bank but to also fund a global property portfolio. The financial crisis in 2008, the world property crash and Anglo Irish Bank's collapse led to him being bankrupted. Anglo Irish Bank was rescued with billions of euros from Irish and European taxpayers and then nationalised. Quinn's losses personified the demise of the Celtic Tiger years of extraordinary growth much of it fuelled with easily available credit. Although the bankrupted former billionaire turned up in court on Friday, most of the day was taken up with cross examination by one of the Anglo trio's lawyers of Quinn's former CEO Liam McCaffrey. Patrick Whelan's lawyer asked McCaffrey if Sean Quinn had lost billions on a "spectacular punt" on shares through contracts for difference, which are bets on future shares in a company. The former head of the Quinn Group of companies replied: "He paid a very high price for investing in that bank." The lawyer for Whelan, Brendan Grehan, said in 2008 the Quinn family had "handed over the keys of the shop" to the bank after it put its businesses up as security for further loans from Anglo Irish. Earlier the court heard that Quinn was "eternally optimistic" about the shares in Anglo Irish Bank recovering in price despite them plummeting in the year of the financial crash. Sean Quinn meanwhile is now expected to give evidence at the trial on Monday morning. The case continues.
fields.headline: Anglo Irish Bank trial: day three
fields.trailText: Jury hears minutes of a meeting between Sean Quinn and the Irish regulator in 2008, while most of the day was taken up with cross examination of former Quinn Group CEO Liam McCaffrey

webTitle: Sports Direct confirms it will bid for Irish retailer Elverys

fields.standfirst: Buyout of struggling sports chain would allow British firm to sell replica rugby kits amid row with Adidas over supply restrictions
fields.body:
Sports Direct has confirmed plans to bid for the struggling Elverys sports chain in Ireland as its battle with Adidas over sales of replica sporting kit goes international.

Dave Forsey, the chief executive of Sports Direct, said: "Elverys would be an excellent strategic fit for Sports Direct in the Republic of Ireland, giving us essential access to the important rugby replica kit market."

The British retailer, founded by the Newcastle United owner, Mike Ashley, already owns a 50% stake of the Heatons department store chain in Ireland.

In a similar move to its restriction on supply of Adidas-sponsored Chelsea replica kit to Sports Direct and other stores in the UK, the German brand intends to limit supply of the locally important Munster rugby team kit to Heatons from this autumn.

Heatons is already restricted from selling Leinster rugby kit sponsored by Canterbury, a brand owned by Pentland Group which is a major shareholder in rival JD Sports.

Adidas announced plans to restrict sales of certain replica kit items from football and other sports across Europe last year.

It said at the time: "Like all manufacturers, we regularly review, season by season, where our products are distributed. We determine distribution channels for all products based on criteria such as in-store environment and customer service levels."

Sports Direct is furious about the plan, which will also affect football World Cup team kits including Germany and Spain in the run-up to the competition this summer.

Forsey said on Friday that the restrictions on Munster rugby kit would result in higher prices for shoppers in Ireland. "The current Adidas segmentation policy is not in the interests of consumers," he said.

Adidas said that only 17 out of 202 retailers in the UK and Ireland were affected by its new distribution policy and added: "Heatons continues to be an important retailer for Adidas and their customers still have the opportunity to buy a great range of Adidas products in their stores."

Sports Direct, which has been widely criticised in the UK over its use of zero-hours contracts for shopfloor staff, is flagging up the Adidas row as it attempts to win support for its Elverys bid after elbowing its way into takeover talks last weekend.

Ireland's oldest sports chain with 55 stores, Elverys was to be sold to a management buyout team backed by the Irish financial firm Capnua.

The deal was expected to be sewn up via a pre-pack administration, but this week the matter went into an open court process after Ashley flew to Dublin to personally intervene.

Ireland's high court appointed an interim examiner to Staunton Sports, the owner of Elverys, this week. Once that role is confirmed, interested parties including Sports Direct will be asked to submit investment proposals to ensure the survival of the business.

Ashley has already offered to pay €2.5m (£2.1m) more than the €10m offered by the Elverys management.

Elverys has been on the market for some months as part of efforts by its owners, John and James Staunton, to settle debts with Ireland's National Asset Management Agency, the "bad bank" that took on property development loans in the wake of the financial crash.

Buying Elverys would consolidate Sports Direct's position in Ireland where it has 26 of its own-branded stores, has recently launched online and owns a 50% stake in Heatons, which has nearly 50 stores across Northern Ireland and the Republic.

webTitle: Bank of England 'knew about' forex markets price fixing

fields.standfirst: Notes from 2012 meeting reportedly show key Bank officials were told of rival currency dealers' sharing of customer orders
fields.body:
The Bank of England has been dragged into the mounting controversy over allegations of price fixing in the £3tn-a-day foreign exchange markets after it emerged that a group of traders had told the Bank they were exchanging information about their clients' position.

The latest twist in the unfolding saga – already the subject of investigations by regulators around the world – puts the focus on a meeting between key officials at the central bank and leading foreign exchange dealers in April 2012, when they discussed the way they handled trades ahead of the crucial setting of a benchmark in the prices of major currencies. This benchmark is used to price a wide variety of financial products and is the subject of regulators' attention amid allegations that traders at rival banks were sharing information about their orders from clients to manipulate the price.

The Bank of England has previously released brief details of the April 2012 meeting, but Bloomberg reported that a senior trader who attended the meeting had made notes showing that officials did not believe it was improper to share customer orders.

According to Bloomberg, there had been a 15-minute conversation on currency benchmarks during which traders said they used chatrooms – now banned by many banks – to trade ahead of the volatile period when the benchmarks were set. The notes have been given to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), which is among the regulators – including ones in the US, Switzerland and Asia – investigating potential manipulation.

The record of the meeting released by the Bank shows it was chaired by Martin Mallett, its chief currency dealer, and includes an entry entitled "extra item". The record says: "Processes around fixes. There was a brief discussion on extra levels of compliance that many bank trading desks were subject to when managing client risks around the main set-piece benchmark fixings."

The Bank would not provide any additional information about the meeting of its so-called foreign exchange joint standing committee and said it was "continuing to support" the FCA with its investigation.

As the FCA's investigation becomes more detailed, it would be in traders' interests to suggest that the Bank knew about their activities, which they raised at a time when there was increasing scrutiny of the Libor setting process. The latter has since resulted in huge fines for Barclays, UBS, Royal Bank of Scotland, Icap and Rabobank. More Libor fines are expected.

Martin Wheatley, chief executive of the FCA, told MPs on the Treasury select committee at the start of this week that the allegations were "every bit as bad" as those surrounding Libor.

The chairman of that committee, Conservative MP Andrew Tyrie, on Friday said the allegations were "extremely serious" and urged the government to implement regulatory changes recommended by the parliamentary commission on banking standards, which he also chaired, and was set up in the wake of the Libor scandal, which he also chaired.

Tyrie said: "These included making individuals personally responsible for lapses in standards, supported by sanctions. Among the most important were the commission's recommendations that remuneration incentivise good, not poor, behaviour. A fundamental reform of the structure of variable pay – which, for too long, has incentivised people to do the wrong thing – is needed."

In December it was reported that banks had known about the processes around setting the benchmark as long ago as 2009.

The scrutiny of the foreign exchange markets has put a fresh focus on dealers leaving banks. More than 20 traders at banks around the world are said to have been suspended or left roles in connection with the forex investigations.

Graeme King, co-head of foreign exchange spot trading at RBC Capital Markets, was said to have left. The bank said: "We do not comment on employee matters, but any suggestion that this is related to the broader FX regulatory investigations is incorrect."

Barclays has also appointed an interim head of its foreign exchange desk after Chris Ashton was suspended. He is Daniel Ryan, who only joined a year ago and was described as "junior trader" by the Financial Times. Ryan is former head of a foreign exchange trading desk at Citi in Singapore and joined Barclays as a director.

webTitle: US jobless rate hits five-year low; ECB's eurozone rescue plan referred to ECJ - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• US non-farm payroll report shows fewer jobs created last month than expected, but the unemployment rate fell to just 6.6%
  • Analysts reaction starts here
  • The key charts
  • Earlier: German constitutional court asks ECJ to rule on ECB’s bond-buying plan
fields.body:
5.50pm GMT

Greek court declares emergency property tax illegal

In Greece, the country’s Supreme Court has just declared an emergency property tax slapped on home owners via electricty bills to be unconstitutional. Helena Smith in Athens writes;

In what is bound to be another headache for Greece’s shaky two-party government, the nation’s Supreme Court, or Areo Pagos, judged that an emergency property tax, levied through electricity bills, was not only unfair but - by being unconstitutional- illegal to boot. With a ruling of three to two, Supreme Court judges argued that the tax, known commonly as the “haratsi,” was wrong because it was calculated on the size of a property and not the economic means of tax payers already hit by an array of tax hikes, wage and pension cuts since the country descended into economic crisis.

The verdict, which has yet to be rubberstamped, ruled that the relentless fiscal obligations imposed on citizens was an affront to their right to live with dignity and equality.

Initially imposed as a temporary “emergency” tax in 2011, the levy has helped plug fiscal holes but is indisputably the most unpopular measure taken since the debt crisis began. From pensioners downwards, Greeks have seen their tax obligations increase seven-fold since 2010, prompting parliament’s independent budgetary office last week to also announce that the imposition of so many taxes had not only exhausted Greeks but had become counter-productive in that it was now fuelling tax evasion.

The ruling follows a series of judgments by the Council of State, the highest legal body in the land, declaring that wage cuts and loss of benefits imposed on security forces, doctors and university professors also be reimbursed by the state.

And on that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we’ll be back again on Monday morning.

5.23pm GMT

Still with ratings, Standard and Poor’s has moved the outlook for Turkey from stable to negative. Its rating is still BB+.

5.09pm GMT

European markets end week on positive note

Despite a rather mixed picture from the US non-farm payrolls reports, and weak Chinese services PMI data, the rally which began on Thursday has not run out of steam. The final scores were:

• The FTSE 100 finished 13.40 points or 0.2% higher at 6571.68

• Germany’s Dax added 0.49% to 9301.92

• France’s Cac closed 0.96% higher at 4228.18

• Italy’s FTSE MIB ended 0.96% better at 19,692.08

• Spain’s Ibex rose 1.08% to 10,072.4

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 84 points or 0.54% higher.

5.03pm GMT

Fitch downgrades Ukraine

Perhaps not the biggest surprise in the world, but ratings agency Fitch has downgraded Ukraine.

The move, from B- to CCC, comes ahead of the next timetabled rating review by Fitch, due on 28 February. But given the political and debt problems facing the country Fitch said:

Fitch interprets [EU regulations] as allowing us to publish a rating review in situations where there is a material change in the creditworthiness of the issuer that we believe makes it inappropriate for us to wait until the next scheduled review... Fitch believes that developments in Ukraine warrant such a deviation from the calendar and our rationale for this is laid out below.

It added:

Political instability has increased markedly since Fitch’s last rating review on 8 November 2013, adding to pressure on the sovereign credit profile. Street protests initially triggered at the end of November by the government’s decision to reject an Association Agreement with the EU increased in scale and violence in mid-January, claiming several lives. The government response to the protests has weakened its popular legitimacy and put diplomatic ties under strain. Mykola Azarov resigned as Prime Minister at the end of January along with the rest of the government.

Sovereign access to external financing and the sovereign’s ability to refinance a heavy external debt repayment schedule, have deteriorated. Russia lent Ukraine $3bn of a $15bn lending package agreed in December, but has put further disbursements on hold pending the formation of a new government. Fitch has previously warned that further Russian support is likely conditional on President Yanukovych’s continued political survival. We no longer assume the Russian loan will be disbursed in full, while Ukraine has lost external market access.

The full report is here:

Fitch Downgrades Ukraine to ‘CCC’

4.34pm GMT

Irish Premier Enda Kenny has claimed Yahoo’s decision to move its data processing headquarters to Dublin has nothing to do with “tax reasons.” Henry McDonald writes:

The Internet search company has switched its operations from Switzerland to the Republic prompting French claims Yahoo made the move because of Ireland’s low corporation tax.

Commenting on Yahoo’s switch, the Taoiseach said: “This is a commercial decision by Yahoo. It is not a directed decision from anybody.”

But Kenny also defended Ireland’s low 12.5% corporation tax regime:

“We have all of these companies in Ireland and the cluster impact creates its own energy and its own dynamism and it’s own structure. Ireland has been very forthright and very upfront about our corporate tax position.”

4.21pm GMT

Ukraine’s central bank has imposed capital controls to bolster its currency as the country’s political and debt crisis continues.

The controls include a limit on private transfers abroad of around $5,700 a month or 50,000 hryvnia and bans on purchases of foreign currency for overseas investment or early repayment of loans.

The full story is here (via Reuters):

Ukraine imposes currency controls amid political crisis

Updated at 4.21pm GMT

3.28pm GMT

More from the Anglo Irish trial continuing in Dublin. Henry McDonald writes:

Ireland’s one time richest man Sean Quinn admitted to Ireland’s financial regulator that he needed to be “reigned in” over his build up of investments in the now defunct Anglo Irish Bank, the trial of three top Irish bankers was told today.

Ahead of Quinn’s own appearance in the witness box at Dublin’s Central Criminal Court today, the 15 strong jury heard that Quinn himself said he had “been greedy” in his acquisition of shares in the bank that eventually almost bankrupted Ireland.

The former billionaire who lost his fortune by borrowings billions from the Anglo Irish Bank is expected to give evidence shortly against three ex-bankers - Sean Fitzpatrick, Patrick Whelan and William McAteer.

The trio are standing trial for unlawfully providing finance for 16 individuals including Sean Quinn in 2008. All three Anglo Irish Bank executives pleaded not guilty to the charges on day one of the court case on Wednesday.

On the third day of what is expected to be one of the complex financial crime trials, the court heard that Quinn made his comments to the Republic’s Financial Regulator Pat Neary during a meeting with him in February 2008 just months before the bank’s collapse.

His former chief executive of the Quinn Group, whose business ranged from concrete to insurance, Liam McCaffrey, revealed to the court that the regulator had fined his boss a record €3.5m for the way the tycoon was managing inter-company loans in order to keep a 24% stake in Anglo Irish Bank.

The case earlier heard that Quinn was “eternally optimistic” about the shares in Anglo Irish Bank despite them plummeting in the year of the financial crash.

3.02pm GMT

The jobless data present a quandary for the US Federal Reserve, according to Unicredit Research chief US economist Dr Harm Bandholz:

Today’s report aggravates the problem for the Fed that we highlighted after the December employment report: On the one hand, the ongoing decline in the unemployment rate – which is now only 0.1 percentage point above the threshold in the forward guidance – means that an adjustment of the forward guidance is becoming more urgent. Atlanta Fed President Lockhart, the FOMC’s median voice, said on Wednesday: “When we get close to or even beyond the 6.5%, I think it is reasonable to expect the Federal Open Market Committee will revise forward guidance, maybe even well before that, to help the markets and the public have an ability to gauge how the economy is performing relative to some sense of goal.”

On the other hand, the second lackluster payroll gain in a row at least questions whether the Fed will continue to moderate its asset purchases at its upcoming meeting. Our baseline view is that the clear majority of FOMC members wants to go on with the tapering and that it needs a string of fundamentally weak numbers to halt the tapering train. While the payroll numbers for December and January, as well as some other economic numbers for this period, have indeed disappointed, one must not forget that a good part of the weakness was caused by unusually cold winter weather.

Ahead of the mid-March FOMC meeting, we will get several other data releases, including the February employment report, which should paint a less biased picture of the economy. If numbers improve as we expect, given our underlying optimism on the economic outlook, the Fed will continue to reduce the pace of its asset purchases in March.

2.51pm GMT

US adds fewer jobs than expected in January but jobless rate improves

From New York, our Wall Street correspondent Dominic Rushe writes:

The US economy added just 113,00 new jobs in January, according to figures released on Friday, as the winter weather appeared to be taking its toll on the jobs market.

Economists had been expecting the economy to add around 180,000 jobs. This is the second month of disappointing jobs news from the US Department of Labor, which last month surprised economists by saying that the US had added just 74,000 jobs in December, well below the 200,000 some had been expecting. That number has been revised up marginally to 75,000. Last year the economy added an average of 194,000 jobs per month.

Both the number of unemployed persons, at 10.2m, and the unemployment rate, down 0.1% to 6.6%, changed little in January. The percentage of the population in or looking for work edged up to 63% from a three-decade low of 62.8% last month.

The number of long-term unemployed (those jobless for 27 weeks or more) fell by 232,000 but remains high at 3.6 million. These individuals accounted for 35.8% of the unemployed.

The news comes after a last-ditch effort to extend an emergency program for the long-term unemployed failed to pass in the Senate on Thursday.

More here: US adds just 113,000 January jobs as unemployment rate dips to 6.6%

And with that, I’m handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher.

Updated at 2.58pm GMT

2.37pm GMT

DING DING DING. Shares are rising in New York as the chimes of the Wall Street opening bell fade away.

The Dow Jones industrial average has risen 50 points, or 0.3%, in early trades, as traders take the jobs report in their stride.

European markets are also broadly higher too, with the FTSE 100 up 24 points now.

2.19pm GMT

Non-farm, the key charts:

2.16pm GMT

Capital Economics: the taper continues

Paul Ashwort, chief US economist at Capital Economics, also reckons the Fed will continue to slow the pace of its bond-buying programme:

So payroll growth appears to have slowed but, given the strength of economic growth in the second half of last year, we expect to see a rebound in the monthly gains over the next few months.

Moreover, with the unemployment rate down to only 6.6%, the Fed should continue to wind down its asset purchases.

2.15pm GMT

Rob Carnell of ING argues that the underlying picture in the US jobs market is stronger than today’s report shows, saying:

Bad weather in parts of the US that normally don’t experience it at this time of the year probably mean that the number is better than appears in this release. And annual benchmark revisions also muddy the picture, although the news here is actually quite positive – with about half a million more people in work than had previously been calculated.

He reckons the Fed will not be swayed from cutting its bond-programme again.

So whilst markets will doubtless move first on the weak headline payrolls figure, we believe that the labour market release as a whole is not too bad, and expect market reactions to be short-lived. There is little question of the taper being reduced in response to this data.

2.00pm GMT

Ashraf Laidi, chief global strategist of cityindex.co.uk, comments:

Net-net, the jobs figures are considered sufficiently positive for the US economy, but are at risk of re-activating the paradigm of “good news are bad for the market” if they embolden Fed Chairwoman Yellen to make a hawkish testimony at her appearance to Congress next week, arguing for further tapering in monthly asset purchases and potentially jeopardising a fragile US recovery at a time when China, the world’s 2nd largest economy is revealing continued signs of weakness in manufacturing and services.

2.00pm GMT

There’s been a lot of talk about how the US labour market has suffered from inclement weather conditions in December and January, when heavy snow and ice storms struck the country.

However, the breakdown in today’s report shows that 48,000 new jobs were created in the US construction sector -- an industry exposed to the weather.

There were also 21,000 new manufacturing jobs created, and 66 in the “service-providing” sectors. But retailers laid off almost 13,000 workers.

1.47pm GMT

US jobs data leaves markets confused

Markets were uncertain how to react to the worse than expected non-farm payrolls, given the headline figure of 113,000 was lower than forecast but the jobless rate at 6.6% was slightly better than the predicted 6.7%, our market reporter Nick Fletcher writes.

Initially the FTSE 100, up 16 points before the data was released, fell back to show a 10 point loss, but this was soon reversed and the index is currently virtually unchanged.

Dow futures, up around 52 points ahead of the jobs report, are now down 42 points. The US dollar initially slipped back against the yen and the pound.

Updated at 1.47pm GMT

1.45pm GMT

One important point - the Bureau of Labor Statistics has also published annual revisions to its data, showing that US employment was higher in 2013 than it thought.

The total nonfarm employment level for March 2013 was revised upward by 369,000, it said, adding:

After accounting for the annual adjustment to the population controls, the civilian labor force rose by 499,000 in January, and the labor force participation rate edged up to 63.0 percent.

Total employment, as measured by the household survey, increased by 616,000 over the month, and the employment-population ratio increased by 0.2 percentage point to 58.8 percent.

Updated at 2.03pm GMT

1.39pm GMT

US unemployment rate down again

The US unemployment rate has fallen to a new five-year low of 6.6%. That’s the lowest level since the collapse of Lehman Brothers sparked the biggest financial crisis in generations.

And the Labour Force Participation (measuring the percentage of the population either employed or looking for a job) inched a little higher to 63.0%, from 62.8%.

1.33pm GMT

November’s jobs report has been revised up, though -- to show a healthier reading of 274,000 new positions being created, up from 241,000 previously.

1.32pm GMT

In another surprise, there’s no real change to December’s weak non-farm payroll -- it’s only been revised a little higher to 75,000 new jobs, from 74,000.

1.31pm GMT

So, for the second month running, the US jobs report has missed expectations -- remember, Wall Street was expecting an average of 180,000 new jobs.

1.30pm GMT

US jobs data released

Breaking: Just 113,000 new jobs were created in the US economy in December, the Bureau of Labour Statistics reports.

1.29pm GMT

Bloomberg tracks all the various forecasts, predictions and guesses for the jobs report -- and it looks like the consensus has slipped to around 150,000 new jobs....

1.21pm GMT

US jobs data coming soon

Right, nearly time for the main economic news of the day -- America’s employment report.

January’s Non-farm payroll, which will be released at 1.30pm sharp, will show how many new jobs were created across the world’s largest economy last month.

On average, economists predict that 180,000 workers were hired (excluding the volatile agriculture sector) last month. The unemployment rate is expected to remain unchanged at 6.7%.

It’s also possible that December NFP will be revised higher -- last month, the Labour ministry stunned the markets by saying a meagre 74,000 new jobs were created.

Other important readings include the labour force participation rate, which measures the percentage of eligible adults actually in work or looking for it. The figures could also be hit by the expiration of emergency jobless welfare payments at the end of last year.

1.05pm GMT

Phillip Inman: Germany's threat to Draghi's bazooka is suspended

Here’s economics correspondent Phillip Inman on today’s German court decision (full coverage starts at 9am GMT)

A threat by Germany to outlaw the European Central Bank’s most effective financial backstop for crisis-hit eurozone countries has been suspended after judges referred the dispute to Europe’s highest court.

The German Constitutional Court said doubts about the ultimate effects of the policy had persuaded it to set aside fears that the ECB’s plan went beyond its remit and could result in taxpayers in richer countries subsiding poorer states.

Passing the decision to the European Court of Justice, the German judges said it may be possible for the ECB to give countries on the edge of bankruptcy funds through its Outright Monetary Transactions (OMT) policy without breaching its rules. The European court is expected to rubber-stamp the policy.

The policy, unveiled by ECB chief Mario Draghi in August 2012 allows the central bank to buy up unlimited amounts of the sovereign debt of crisis-ridden countries.

While it has not so far been put into action, its mere existence has effectively defused fears of an imminent break-up of the eurozone, and as such has proved the most effective tool in calming the crisis.

Eighteen months ago the German court backed two other key eurozone crisis tools - the €500m European Stability Mechanism bailout fund, and the European fiscal pact.

Today’s move by the German court was widely seen as a way to dodge a decision that had become highly charged over the last year.

The constitutional court had agreed to rule on the OMT under pressure from eurosceptics, who want to impose a German veto on “under the counter” ECB subsidies.

Judges at the court, which is based in Karlsruhe, made an initial assessment backing the eurospecticsand finding the OMT programme to be illegal – saying there were “important reasons to assume that it [the OMT programme] exceeds the ECB’s monetary policy mandate and thus infringes the powers of the member states”.

However, the court has now said it was not completely convinced by its own assessment. It said the ECB could impose stringent requirements that offset the huge subsidies that flow from rescuing a member state from financial collapse.

Carsten Brzeski, a eurozone analyst at Dutch bank ING, said:

“The announcement could either be a sign that the court has reached its legal limits on European issues or that the issue is so tricky and touchy that it is better to pass it on.”

In the short term, he said the announcement “should clearly reduce the Karlsruhe fear factor for the ECB”.

The German constitutional court said it would issue its final ruling on the €500m ESM on March 18.

But it also decided to consult the European Court of Justice with regard to the OMT because the ECB as a European body comes under the jurisdiction of the Luxembourg-based court.

It would be the first time that the constitutional court has passed on a case to the European court.

Updated at 1.06pm GMT

12.42pm GMT

Over to Greece, the government is hoping for help from the European Union in dealing with its quake-rattled island of Cephalonia, now being described as a natural disaster zone.

As Helena Smith reports from Athens, the appeal was made last night:

After rushing in the army, dispatching tents and declaring a state of emergency, Athens’ coalition government has now appealed to the European Solidarity Fund for help to cope with the natural disaster that has unfolded on Cephalonia. The western Ionian island has been rattled by a series of quakes (the latest last night) since being convulsed by two strong temblors, the first 12 days ago. With more than 3,000 buildings damaged (and over 700 now needing to be torn down) inhabitants have resorted to sleeping in their cars with seismologists not ruling out the area being hit again in the imminent future.

Cephalonia – which shot to fame internationally as the setting of Captain Corelli’s Mandolin - has also suffered heavy damage to its infrastructure with its road network, schools and a local port being especially hard hit. For islanders already finding it hard to keep up with spiralling taxes and relentless budget cuts, the crisis could not come at a worse time. The disaster has highlighted the dangers near bankrupt Greece now faces in dealing with anything that, officials say, has not been factored in monetarily.

“If there was ever a natural disaster the country in this state would never be able to cope,” the IMF’s former resident mission chief Bob Traa had told me early on in Greece’s debt crisis. “It’s our worst nightmare.”

Athens may have made fiscal progress in the meantime (last night the Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras told an audience of businessmen in Frankfurt that, like the country’s primary budget surplus, the recession rate in 2013 was likely to be much better than anticipated), but budgets are still especially tight.

Deputy prime minister Evangelos Venizelos requested the aid during talks with Regional Policy Commissioner Johannes Hahn as he attended a conference in Athens (given in Greece’s capacity as EU president), on strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian areas. Venizelos is believed to have conveyed the government’s concerns that if allowed to go unchecked the natural disaster will effect tourism, the island’s mainstay. Islanders have already been offered relief in the form of government grants to help cover damage and a reprieve from paying property taxes.

12.19pm GMT

Interesting take (as ever) from FT Alphaville-- arguing the GCC have missed the whole point of OMT.

I flagged up earlier that the court reckoned it could be legal if it wasn’t unlimited and didn’t distort the markets. This, Alphaville explains, gets Mario Draghi’s objectives and the OMT’s technical features backwards:

That the OMT would be pari passu with ordinary bondholders — in other words, that the ECB would observe the ordinary terms of the assets it was buying and not cheat by seeking special treatment — was very important for markets. One reason the SMP could never have supported Spain and Italy was that size meant more subordination for private creditors precisely when the risk of sovereign default was high: the SMP was senior.

That the OMT would be ex ante unlimited, meanwhile, was the whole point of its magic: it is a very difficult commitment for the market to test, ex ante, by the same token. This is why the OMT has worked without ever, actually, being activated.

More here: The OMT — um, what does this thing do again? A Bundesverfassungsgericht guide

11.45am GMT

EC welcomes German move

The German constitutional court’s decision to chuck the OMT hot potato into the hands of the European Court of Justice has just been welcomed by the European Commission.

Spokesman Simon O’Connor said:

“It’s the first time that the (German) court has taken such a decision.

We welcome the fact that the court has referred this question to the European Court of Justice.”

On that point, Christian Odendahl of Roubini Global Economics argues that Germany’s constitutional court in Karlsruhe has slightly dented its own authority:

Although one astute fund manager in London points to Germany’s maturity over the issue:

11.28am GMT

Open Europe have now published their ‘flash analysis’ of the German constitutional court (GCC) ruling.

They warn that the OMT is now ‘in limbo’ while the European Court of Justice examines the Outright Monetary Transactions programme, and also point out that the GCC will eventually give its own view.

Will the GCC still provide its own ruling?

Yes, but likely only after the ECJ has ruled. The GCC seems to be stuck. It has serious concerns over the OMT and its compatibility with the EU treaties and German law. However, it feels it cannot rule on issues of German law until the questions over EU law have been settled – which are outside of its jurisdiction. Once the ECJ has ruled, the GCC will likely re-examine how the OMT fits with German law, however, it will be constrained by the ECJ’s ruling and interpretation of EU law.

Open Europe also warns that the ongoing uncertainty over OMT could cause “jitters” in the eurozone.

For all the talk or institutional and structural change as well as national governments pushing reform, the OMT has been the key factor in easing the crisis. It certainly throws a new bout of uncertainty into the very fragile economic recovery in the eurozone.

Here’s the full note: I’m the German Constitutional Court, get me out of here! Court sees ECB bond buying as illegal but refers questions to ECJ

11.15am GMT

Katie Allen has looked into the Treasury’s bullish claim at 11.06am that UK exports are at a record high...

Yes, they were for 2013 as a whole. But so too were imports.

The ONS says: “In 2013, the deficit on trade in goods narrowed by £0.4 billion to £108.3 billion (annually). The level of exports increased to a record £304.3 billion in 2013, up 1.3% from £300.5 billion in 2012.

However, the rise in exports was accompanied by an increase in imports to a record £412.6 billion in 2013, up 0.8% from £409.2 billion in 2012. Despite these record levels of exports and imports, annual growth in the value of trade in goods has slowed considerably since 2010 and 2011.”

11.06am GMT

UK Treasury: falling trade gap shows recovery on track

In London, the UK Treasury has argued that today’s trade data (a smaller than expected deficit) shows the recovery continues.

A Treasury spokesman said:

“Today’s trade and manufacturing figures provide further evidence that the government’s long-term economic plan is working. Manufacturing has continued its strong growth and goods exports have hit a record high. But the job is not yet done, and as the IFS said only this week ‘the largest challenge for the chancellor remains having to contend with the consequences of the Great Recession for the public finances and household incomes’. That is why it’s so important that we continue to work through the long-term plan that is delivering economic security for Britain’s hardworking people.”

But Martin Beck, UK economist at Capital Economics says today’s data point to some rebalancing but it is by no means plain sailing from here.

He comments:

“December’s figures on industrial production and trade offer some mixed messages on whether the economy is achieving better balanced growth. On the one hand, momentum in industry may be easing. Given flat output in November, December’s monthly rise of 0.3% in manufacturing output was fairly muted. And 0.4% growth in overall industrial production that month fell short of the 0.6% pencilled in by the ONS in its preliminary estimate of Q4 GDP growth. However, on its own, this is not enough to push down the estimated 0.7% rise in GDP in Q4.

“However, the trade data for December showed the UK’s overall deficit in goods and services falling to an unexpectedly small £1bn in December from £3.6bn in the previous month. This was the biggest monthly narrowing since records began in 1998. Exports rose by 1.9% m/m while imports dropped by 4.7%. Note though that the latter was partly down to erratic factors, particularly a drop in imports of planes and ships. So the deficit is likely to widen again next month. Nonetheless, it looks like net trade will have added to growth in the final three months of 2014, following Q3’s hefty drag.

And Lee Hopley, chief economist at manufacturers’ organisation EEF says:

“Manufacturers had a strong finish to 2013, but more encouraging, are the indicators we’ve seen since the start of the year which suggest that positive trend has rolled into the early part of 2014. Our expectation is that we see another quarter of 0.6% expansion in the three months to March, with a pretty even picture across sectors.”

11.04am GMT

10.55am GMT

Over in the FT, Richard Barwell, senior European economist at RBS, is also predicting that the European Court of Justice will, in time, rule in Mario Draghi’s favour:

He said:

“The European Court was always the ultimate judge and jury of whether OMT is treaty compliant, so it makes sense for Karlsruhe to pass the buck for once, but I expect the ECJ to sing from the ECB’s hymn sheet.”

So, it might be case of victory, deferred, for the European Central Bank.

10.48am GMT

University of London European law expert Gunnar Beck reckons that the European Court of Justice is highly likely to rule in the European Central Bank’s favour.

He doesn’t think it will share Germany’s concern that the OMT bond-buying programme would effectively be monetising eurozone debts.

Beck told Reuters that the ECJ will act in the best interest of the EU, rather than taking a strict legal view (!)

“Practically speaking, the Court of Justice is not an independent organization but is pre-disposed to interpret legal questions in the interest of the European Union.

The court of justice doesn’t take account of national sensibilities ... there is no doubt of the outcome now.”

Perhaps that’s why the Karlsruhe court decided to give the ECJ a bit of advice today, by declaring the bond-buying programme probably illegal unless it is only implemented in a restricted way (see here for details)

Updated at 10.48am GMT

10.25am GMT

Brzeski: ECJ may not 'rubber-stamp' ECB's bond-buying programme

Back to the German constitutional court’s decision to ask the European Court of Justice to examine the ECB’s OMT programme (see 9am onwards for full coverage).

ING’s Carsten Brzeski argues that the news removes one short-term threat to the ECB, but adds that the ECJ may have its own concerns about the plan:

The Court just said that there were “important reasons to assume that it [the OMT programme] exceeds the European Central Bank’s monetary policy mandate and thus infringes the powers of the Member States”. In short, the Court gives a long explanation why it thinks that the OMT programme is illegal.

However, there is one passage in the press statement which indicates that the Court is not totally convinced by its own assessment. According to the Court, OMT would be legal if it would not undermine the conditionality of the EFSF and ESM bailout programmes. This, however, in the eyes of the Court would require that the haircut option, which is part of the ESM treaty, should be excluded and that bond purchases are not unlimited. Particularly the issue of conditionality has frequently been emphasised by the ECB.

It does not happen a lot that the German Constitutional Court passes sensitive decisions on to the European level. Today’s announcement therefore could either be a sign that the Court has reached its legal limits on European issues or that the issue is so tricky and touchy that it is better to pass it on. As regards the short-term outlook, the announcement should clearly reduce the Karlsruhe fear factor for the ECB. But not entirely. It is not a given that the European Court of Justice will only rubber-stamp the OMT programme.

10.20am GMT

Turning to the UK briefly, we’ve had mixed economic data this morning.

Official figures show Britain’s trade deficit narrowed sharply at the end of last year but manufacturing failed to grow as strongly as hoped, reports my colleague Katie Allen:

The Office for National Statistics said a rise in exports and a fall in imports helped the UK’s deficit on trade in goods and services fall to an estimated £1bn in December, compared with a deficit of £3.6bn in November.

Trade data are erratic but it is good news for the government as it continues to push for rebalancing of the UK economy towards more external demand.

The goods deficit – easier to assess than trade in services – was £7.7bn, down from £9.8bn in November. That was well below a consensus forecast for a £9.3bn gap in a Reuters poll of economists.

The news on manufacturing, around a tenth of the UK economy, was less upbeat.

The ONS said manufacturing production rose 0.3% on the month in December, half as fast as forecast. The wider industrial sector, which also includes mining and utilities, saw output rise 0.4%, below forecasts for 0.6% growth.

Over the fourth quarter of 2013 both manufacturing and industrial production were weaker than the ONS had estimated when it came up with last month’s growth figure for the economy as a whole of 0.7%. But it said the impact on that estimate was less than 0.05%.

10.11am GMT

Megan Greene, chief economist at Maverick Intelligence, also reckons that the ECB won’t be able to pull the trigger on OMT until the European judges have had their say:

10.06am GMT

Mats Persson of Open Europe reckons the German court have kicked the OMT issue into the long grass, by referring it to the European Court of Justice.

10.03am GMT

Sony Kapoor of the ReDefine think tank argues that today’s ruling will make it harder for the ECB to activate the OMT bond-buying programme in the short term.

But does that matter? The borrowing costs of Spain and Italy - two potential candidates for OMT help - have fallen sharply over the last 18 months since Mario Draghi announced the plan.

They remain calm today -- Italy can borrow at around 3.7% per annum for 10 years, while Spain’s 10-year bonds are trading at 3.6%.

During the crisis, these bonds were trading at alarming yields of 7% or more.

9.55am GMT

The FT’s Brussels expert, Peter Spiegel, and ING’s economist Carsten Brzeski, are both surprised that the German constitutional court could declare OMT probably illegal but refer the issue to the European court of justice:

9.52am GMT

The German judges are also unimpressed by Mario Draghi’s argument that the OMT bond-buying programme will address unwarranted fears that the eurozone might break up.

They say it’s a de facto economic policy (not allowed in the rules):

The classification of the OMT Decision as an act of economic policy is supported by its immediate objective, which is to neutralise spreads on government bonds of selected Member States of the euro currency area.

According to the European Central Bank, these spreads are partly based on fear of investors of a reversibility of the euro; however, according to the Bundesbank, such interest rate spreads only reflect the scepticism of market participants that individual Member States will show sufficient budgetary discipline to stay permanently solvent.

9.49am GMT

Some eurocrisis experts point out that the European Court of Justice is unlikely to make an early ruling on the legality of the OMT programme - suggesting we might not get a ruling until 2016.

9.41am GMT

ECB hits back

The European Central Bank has swiftly declared that its OMT programme does not breach European rules, whatever those German judges say.

Updated at 10.13am GMT

9.33am GMT

Why Germany's judges don't like OMT

Skimming today’s statement from Germany, the constitutional court judges voted 6-2 that there are “important reasons” to assume that the OMT bond-buying programme would effectively be monetary financing -- in other words, one member state’s budgets being financed by another.

The Maastricht Treaty strictly forbids monetary financing.

The judges say:

In the view of the Senate, there are important reasons to assume that it exceeds the European Central Bank’s monetary policy mandate and thus infringes the powers of the Member States, and that it violates the prohibition of monetary financing of the budget.

adding:

The violation would be manifest because primary law stipulates an explicit prohibition of monetary financing of the budget and thus unequivocally excludes such powers of the European Central Bank.

However, they also suggest that OMT could still be legal if there is no reduction in a country’s national debt, and if the ECB does not buy “unlimited amounts”, and if it doesn’t unduly affect the financial markets.

In the view of the Federal Constitutional Court, the OMT Decision might not be objectionable... [if] the acceptance of a debt cut must be excluded, that government bonds of selected Member States are not purchased up to unlimited amounts, and that interferences with price formation on the market are to be avoided where possible.

9.21am GMT

This is the first time that Germany’s constitutional court has referred a case to the European Court of Justice, flags up Nina Schick of Open Europe.

9.20am GMT

Key event

There’s no immediate panic in the markets. The euro only fell slightly - down around 0.2% against the US dollar.

9.15am GMT

The statement from the German constitutional court, referring the ECB’s OMT bond-buying programme to the European Court of Justice, is online here.

9.00am GMT

German constitutional court: ECB's bond-buying pledge could exceed its mandate

Some important news out of Germany -- its constitutional court has declared that the European Central Bank’s bond-buying programme may exceed its mandate, and referred it to European Court of Justice.

Germany’s highest court warned that the ECB’s Outright Monetary Transaction programme could infringe the central bank’s mandate -- although it might be acceptable if implemented in a limited way.

Reuters has the quotes:

The court said it sees “important reasons to assume that it exceeds the European Central Bank’s monetary policy mandate and thus infringes the powers of the member states, and that it violates the prohibition of monetary financing of the budget”.

However, the court said in a statement that it “also considers it possible that if the OMT Decision were interpreted restrictively” it could conform with law.

Judges in Karlsruhe have been deliberating for months over OMT, with some analysts warning that it could jam a hefty spoke into the wheels of Mario Draghi’s crisis-calming measures.

Although OMT has never been activated, the pledge to buy unlimited quantities of eurozone government bonds if a country suffered borrowing problems helped calm the crisis 18 months ago.

Only yesterday, Mario Draghi told reporters that the ECB had the power to buy government bonds in the so-called secondary debt market.

More to follow....

Updated at 9.05am GMT

8.51am GMT

London’s property market remains pretty hot, according to Shaftesbury, the owner of property in London‘s Soho and other West End districts

The company told the City this morning that demand was strong across properties in Carnaby Street, Chinatown, Charlotte Street and other West End “villages” in the four months to 6 February.

Existing sites are virtually fully let and businesses are snapping up refurbished properties as they come on the market.

More here: London West End property owner says business remains strong

8.37am GMT

An unexpected drop in exports has helped to trim Germany’s trade surplus.

The Federal Statistics Office reports that German exports fell 0.9% month-on-month in December, from €93.3bn to €92.5bn. Imports dipped 0.6%, from €74.4bn to €74bn.

This meant the December trade balance came in at +€18.5bn, down from November’s €18.9bn - but still rather higher than the €16.9bn recorded a year earlier.

8.26am GMT

Not a great morning for pharmaceuticals firm Shire, though -- it’s leading the FTSE 100 fallers, down 1.6%, after telling shareholders last night its Vyvanse drug had failed two late-stage clinical trials to see if it worked as an anti-depression treatment (updated).

Updated at 9.56am GMT

8.22am GMT

European markets are also up in early trading -- adding to some strong gains yesterday. Nothing spectacular ; the Russian MICEX is the best performer, up 0.5%.

Updated at 8.22am GMT

8.06am GMT

Here’s the details of the Asian rally overnight, led by Japan -- with the Nikkei up 2.1% rise and the broader Topix gaining 2.3%.

Updated at 8.12am GMT

7.55am GMT

Will non-farm payroll show US job creation on track?

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the main events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

The big event in the markets today is the US Non-Farm Payroll (NFP) report, the monthly measure of employment in the world’s largest economy, released at 1.30pm GMT.

After December’s surprisingly poor report (just 74,000 new jobs were created), economists are looking for a stronger reading today -- and some reckon last month’s report could also be revised higher.

It could also show the US jobless rate falling from last month’s 6.7% -- though that can be a mixed blessing if it’s simply due to workers quitting the labour force altogether.

The NFP has global implication. A strong report will vindicate the Federal Reserve’s decision to reduce (or taper) its bond-buying stimulus programme -- sending spillover effects rippling through emerging markets). Another poor report could give Janet Yellen and the rest of the Fed something to ponder.

Wall Street, and most European stock markets, rallied yesterday afternoon on hopes that today’s reading will show the US economy healing -- and Asia has followed suit overnight. Japan’s Nikkei jumped over 2%, while the Chinese Shanghai index rose a gentle 0.6% on the first day of trading after the Lunar New Year break.

The consensus estimate is that NFP will how around 180,000 new jobs created in the US last month, although estimates do vary considerably (economists are struggling to work out how much disruption was caused by recent wintery weather) .

While Stan Shamu of IG reckons the big question is how emerging markets respond to the data:

Given tapering now seems to be on a set course, it is important to see US jobs stabilising to help underpin confidence. Eight out of the last nine payrolls releases have seen US equities gain ground and if that counts for anything we could be in for an extension of gains.

It’ll be important to watch emerging markets closely and how they react to the jobs numbers.

In the meantime, the latest UK trade data (at 9.30am GMT) will show how Britain’s economy performed in December. We’ve already seen a surprise drop in German exports this morning (more in a moment).

We’ll be tracking all the main events through the day as usual.

Updated at 8.02am GMT
fields.bodyText: In Greece, the country’s Supreme Court has just declared an emergency property tax slapped on home owners via electricty bills to be unconstitutional. Helena Smith in Athens writes; In what is bound to be another headache for Greece’s shaky two-party government, the nation’s Supreme Court, or Areo Pagos, judged that an emergency property tax, levied through electricity bills, was not only unfair but - by being unconstitutional- illegal to boot. With a ruling of three to two, Supreme Court judges argued that the tax, known commonly as the “haratsi,” was wrong because it was calculated on the size of a property and not the economic means of tax payers already hit by an array of tax hikes, wage and pension cuts since the country descended into economic crisis. The verdict, which has yet to be rubberstamped, ruled that the relentless fiscal obligations imposed on citizens was an affront to their right to live with dignity and equality. Initially imposed as a temporary “emergency” tax in 2011, the levy has helped plug fiscal holes but is indisputably the most unpopular measure taken since the debt crisis began. From pensioners downwards, Greeks have seen their tax obligations increase seven-fold since 2010, prompting parliament’s independent budgetary office last week to also announce that the imposition of so many taxes had not only exhausted Greeks but had become counter-productive in that it was now fuelling tax evasion. The ruling follows a series of judgments by the Council of State, the highest legal body in the land, declaring that wage cuts and loss of benefits imposed on security forces, doctors and university professors also be reimbursed by the state. And on that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we’ll be back again on Monday morning. Still with ratings, Standard and Poor’s has moved the outlook for Turkey from stable to negative. Its rating is still BB+. Despite a rather mixed picture from the US non-farm payrolls reports, and weak Chinese services PMI data, the rally which began on Thursday has not run out of steam. The final scores were: • The FTSE 100 finished 13.40 points or 0.2% higher at 6571.68 • Germany’s Dax added 0.49% to 9301.92 • France’s Cac closed 0.96% higher at 4228.18 • Italy’s FTSE MIB ended 0.96% better at 19,692.08 • Spain’s Ibex rose 1.08% to 10,072.4 On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 84 points or 0.54% higher. Perhaps not the biggest surprise in the world, but ratings agency Fitch has downgraded Ukraine. The move, from B- to CCC, comes ahead of the next timetabled rating review by Fitch, due on 28 February. But given the political and debt problems facing the country Fitch said: Fitch interprets [EU regulations] as allowing us to publish a rating review in situations where there is a material change in the creditworthiness of the issuer that we believe makes it inappropriate for us to wait until the next scheduled review... Fitch believes that developments in Ukraine warrant such a deviation from the calendar and our rationale for this is laid out below. It added: Political instability has increased markedly since Fitch’s last rating review on 8 November 2013, adding to pressure on the sovereign credit profile. Street protests initially triggered at the end of November by the government’s decision to reject an Association Agreement with the EU increased in scale and violence in mid-January, claiming several lives. The government response to the protests has weakened its popular legitimacy and put diplomatic ties under strain. Mykola Azarov resigned as Prime Minister at the end of January along with the rest of the government. Sovereign access to external financing and the sovereign’s ability to refinance a heavy external debt repayment schedule, have deteriorated. Russia lent Ukraine $3bn of a $15bn lending package agreed in December, but has put further disbursements on hold pending the formation of a new government. Fitch has previously warned that further Russian support is likely conditional on President Yanukovych’s continued political survival. We no longer assume the Russian loan will be disbursed in full, while Ukraine has lost external market access. The full report is here: Fitch Downgrades Ukraine to ‘CCC’ Irish Premier Enda Kenny has claimed Yahoo’s decision to move its data processing headquarters to Dublin has nothing to do with “tax reasons.” Henry McDonald writes: The Internet search company has switched its operations from Switzerland to the Republic prompting French claims Yahoo made the move because of Ireland’s low corporation tax. Commenting on Yahoo’s switch, the Taoiseach said: “This is a commercial decision by Yahoo. It is not a directed decision from anybody.” But Kenny also defended Ireland’s low 12.5% corporation tax regime: “We have all of these companies in Ireland and the cluster impact creates its own energy and its own dynamism and it’s own structure. Ireland has been very forthright and very upfront about our corporate tax position.” Ukraine’s central bank has imposed capital controls to bolster its currency as the country’s political and debt crisis continues. The controls include a limit on private transfers abroad of around $5,700 a month or 50,000 hryvnia and bans on purchases of foreign currency for overseas investment or early repayment of loans. The full story is here (via Reuters): Ukraine imposes currency controls amid political crisis More from the Anglo Irish trial continuing in Dublin. Henry McDonald writes: Ireland’s one time richest man Sean Quinn admitted to Ireland’s financial regulator that he needed to be “reigned in” over his build up of investments in the now defunct Anglo Irish Bank, the trial of three top Irish bankers was told today. Ahead of Quinn’s own appearance in the witness box at Dublin’s Central Criminal Court today, the 15 strong jury heard that Quinn himself said he had “been greedy” in his acquisition of shares in the bank that eventually almost bankrupted Ireland. The former billionaire who lost his fortune by borrowings billions from the Anglo Irish Bank is expected to give evidence shortly against three ex-bankers - Sean Fitzpatrick, Patrick Whelan and William McAteer. The trio are standing trial for unlawfully providing finance for 16 individuals including Sean Quinn in 2008. All three Anglo Irish Bank executives pleaded not guilty to the charges on day one of the court case on Wednesday. On the third day of what is expected to be one of the complex financial crime trials, the court heard that Quinn made his comments to the Republic’s Financial Regulator Pat Neary during a meeting with him in February 2008 just months before the bank’s collapse. His former chief executive of the Quinn Group, whose business ranged from concrete to insurance, Liam McCaffrey, revealed to the court that the regulator had fined his boss a record €3.5m for the way the tycoon was managing inter-company loans in order to keep a 24% stake in Anglo Irish Bank.
